content: Spin waves in condensed matter are a current and well-studied topic in modern physics. However, there is a less-known backwater in this field: Torsion Fields, the quantum spin of empty space; the large-scale coherent effects of the spin of the particles in the virtual sea. Initial work in this field was performed by Einstein and Cartan in the 1920's, now known as ECT (Einstein-Cartan-theory.) Currently there are rumors that spin waves have real physical consequences, and that useful technology can be based on such things. If "torsion fields" can be used for communication, they could explain such things as telepathy and PK. Most of the recent work has been done in Russia, but now and then interesting things appear in the US as well. So the practical application for this would be for space communications to and from Spacecraft that are on extended missions. If a craft were traveling to Mars for instance, communications would be instantaneous. High speed communications for probes and equipment designed for operating on a far off planet and controlled by a Technician on the Earth. I think that some of the Scientists are worried that the space between the two communication nodes could be hazardous space. Kinda like a microwave? or something like that. Quantum materiae materietur marmota monax si marmota monax materiam possit materiari?

content: As someone already alluded, improvement on the speed of communication would be marginal at best. Speaking of which, anyone care to guess when the last time we had a drastic improvement on speed of communication? 1837 - the invention of the telegraph. Every other improvement since then has been in volume, portability, and medium of communication, but not speed. Lincoln received messages from his commanders in the field in about the same amount of time as Obama. Sullivan013

content: quote: Originally posted by mikeyR8: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: quote: Originally posted by Ruanne: That's not a moon, that's a space station! The moon as a station makes more sense than the ISS. International Moon Station. Will Obama Check it out? Did you ever hear of a TV series called Space 1999? An artificial satellite like the ISS has certain advantages over the moon - it's closer for a start, handy if you need to bang out in a hurry. It also has effectively no gravity which if important for a number of experiments (and may have future industrial applications) where as the Moon's gravity is enough to ruin many experiments. It would probably make more sense to build some sort of bigger station at the Earth Moon L-1 Lagrange point I suppose as you'd need to worry less about the orbit decaying.
quote: Originally posted by mikeyR8: quote: Originally posted by sargeant_green: quote: Originally posted by Ruanne: That's not a moon, that's a space station! The moon as a station makes more sense than the ISS. International Moon Station. Will Obama Check it out?
